Falters at times: The claim falters by suggesting that the photos show violations of COVID-19 safety precautions when they were actually taken before the first case of COVID-19 was identified in Michigan and before face coverings were required.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only provides photos without any additional evidence or context to support the assertion that COVID-19 safety precautions were violated.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that the individuals in the photos were not following COVID-19 safety precautions, without considering the possibility that they may have been exempt or following guidelines that were in place at the time.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation exists for the photos, as they were taken at a Biden campaign rally before the COVID-19 pandemic and safety measures were implemented.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the photos were not taken at the Democratic National Convention or during Biden and Harris' first appearance together, as stated by the expert's verdict.
Understate: The claim understates the context of the photos by failing to mention that they were taken before the first case of COVID-19 in Michigan and before the state required face coverings.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of the photos by implying that they show violations of COVID-19 safety precautions, when in reality they were taken before such precautions were in place.
